questions.text: Based on the type of secretion illustrated in the image, identify the region of the body where such apocrine glands are typically located. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Axilla

 

 

 

Apocrine glands are a type of sweat gland that are primarily found in certain areas of the body. These glands release their secretions in response to emotional stress or hormonal changes. They are different from the more common eccrine sweat glands, which are distributed throughout most of the body and are primarily involved in temperature regulation.

 

  • Axilla: Apocrine glands are predominantly located in the axilla (underarm) region. They become active during puberty and release a thicker, milky secretion that can produce body odor when broken down by skin bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Face: The face contains sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands, but not apocrine glands.

 

Option B. Scalp: The scalp contains numerous sebaceous glands and eccrine sweat glands, but apocrine glands are not typically found in this area.

 

Option C. Palms and soles: The palms and soles have a high concentration of eccrine sweat glands, which are crucial for thermoregulation. Apocrine glands are not found in these regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Apocrine glands are primarily found in the axilla (underarm) region and become active during puberty, releasing thicker secretions that can lead to body odor when metabolized by skin bacteria.

  1. Subcaecal
  2. Retrocaecal
  3. Inside the pelvis
  4. Paracaecal
questions.solution: Ans. C) 1-b, 2-d, 3-a, 4-c

questions.text: 2,3 BPG binds with which of the following? (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Globin part of hemoglobin

 

Option B. Globin part of hemoglobin: 2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin. This binding reduces hemoglobin's affinity for oxygen, facilitating oxygen release to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Globin part of myoglobin: 2,3-BPG does not bind to myoglobin. Myoglobin, primarily found in muscle tissue, has a higher affinity for oxygen and does not interact with 2,3-BPG.

 

Option C. Heme part of myoglobin: The heme part of myoglobin binds to oxygen directly; 2,3-BPG does not bind to this site or affect myoglobin's oxygen affinity.

 

Option D. Heme part of hemoglobin: While the heme part of hemoglobin is the site for oxygen binding, 2,3-BPG does not bind here. It binds at a separate site on the globin chains to modulate oxygen affinity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

2,3-BPG binds to the beta chains of the globin part of hemoglobin, reducing its affinity for oxygen and facilitating the release of oxygen to tissues. This interaction is crucial for efficient oxygen delivery in response to tissue demands.

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady came to psychiatry OPD with symptoms of hypomania. There is a past history of maniac episode. Now, she is planning to conceive. Which of the following drug is maximum teratogenic to the fetus?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Valproate

 

  • Valproate is the most teratogenic drug among the drugs used in bipolar disorder and anti-epileptic medications. It causes congenital anomalies like neural tube defects (spina bifida), cleft lip and cleft palate, and cardiac anomalies. It also contributes to poor cognitive development in children.
  • Although lithium is also teratogenic and can cause Ebstein anomaly in the fetus, but it is less teratogenic than valproate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: This medication is also used to treat bipolar disorder and epilepsy, but it has a lower risk of teratogenic effects compared to valproate. The risk of major congenital malformations with lamotrigine is relatively low.

 

Option C. Oxcarbazepine: Used to treat epilepsy and bipolar disorder, oxcarbazepine has a moderate risk of teratogenic effects, but it is still considered less teratogenic than valproate.

 

Option D. Olanzapine: This antipsychotic medication is used for bipolar disorder and schizophrenia. While there are some risks associated with its use during pregnancy, including potential metabolic complications, it is not considered as teratogenic as valproate.

 

Additional Note on Lithium

 

Although lithium is also used to treat bipolar disorder and is known to be teratogenic, causing conditions like Ebstein's anomaly (a heart defect), its teratogenic risk is considered lower than that of valproate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Valproate is the most teratogenic drug among the options listed, causing significant congenital anomalies such as neural tube defects, cleft lip and palate, and cardiac anomalies, as well as poor cognitive development. It should be avoided in women who are planning to conceive or are pregnant.

questions.text:
Which of the following is/are true about optic neuritis? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

I. Disproportionate loss of colour vision and contrast to visual acuity
II. 70% cases of multiple sclerosis are affected
III. Treatment is done by oral steroids
IV. Optic neuritis presents with normal fundus or disc edema
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Only IV

 

  • Optic neuritis is inflammation of the optic nerve that can present in different forms. 
  • Statement IV is correct because optic neuritis can present as either papillitis (with disc edema visible on fundoscopy) or retrobulbar neuritis (with a normal-appearing fundus). 
  • In retrobulbar neuritis, which is the most frequent type in adults and commonly associated with multiple sclerosis, the inflammation occurs behind the eyeball, resulting in the classic description "neither the patient sees anything nor the doctor sees anything" - meaning there's vision loss but the optic disc appears normal. 
  • In papillitis, there is hyperemia and edema of the optic nerve head visible on examination. Neuroretinitis, the least common type, shows a macular star pattern of exudates.

 

Incorrect statements:

 

Statement I - Disproportionate loss of colour vision: This is incorrect. Optic neuritis actually causes proportionate loss of vision, not disproportionate. Patients experience sudden onset vision loss, decreased color vision (particularly red desaturation), and may have a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), but these changes are proportional to the degree of optic nerve damage.

 

Statement II - 70% cases of multiple sclerosis are affected: This is incorrect. The correct statistics are: 50% of multiple sclerosis patients will experience an attack of optic neuritis during their lifetime, not 70%. Additionally, 10-15% of patients with multiple sclerosis present initially with optic neuritis as their first symptom.

 

Statement III - Treatment is done by oral steroids: This is incorrect. According to the Optic Neuritis Treatment Trial (ONTT), the standard treatment is intravenous methylprednisolone (1g/day for 3 days) followed by oral steroids (1mg/kg/day for 11 days). Direct oral steroids without initial IV therapy are actually contraindicated as they may increase the risk of recurrence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optic neuritis can present with either a normal fundus (retrobulbar neuritis) or disc edema (papillitis), and treatment requires initial IV steroids, not oral steroids alone.

 

Note - Optic Neuritis:

questions.text: A patient developed sudden hypertensive episode after taking wine. He is suffering from a psychiatric illness and is on medications for the same. Which is the drug he is likely to be using? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MAOIs

 

The patient in the question is likely taking monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) for his psychiatric illness.

 

MAOIs are known to cause a "Cheese reaction" or hypertensive crisis when combined with tyramine-rich foods like wine, cheese, and pizzas. Normally, tyramine is broken down by monoamine oxidase enzymes in the body. However, when a person is taking MAOIs, these enzymes are inhibited, leading to an accumulation of tyramine. The excess tyramine can cause a sudden and dangerous increase in blood pressure, resulting in a hypertensive episode.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors): Incorrect. SSRIs work by selectively inhibiting the reuptake of serotonin and do not significantly affect the metabolism of tyramine.

 

Option C. SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors): Incorrect. SNRIs work by inhibiting the reuptake of both serotonin and norepinephrine and do not significantly affect the metabolism of tyramine.

 

Option D. TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants): Incorrect. While TCAs can have some effects on blood pressure, they do not inhibit monoamine oxidase enzymes and do not lead to the accumulation of tyramine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs) can cause a "cheese reaction" or hypertensive crisis when combined with tyramine-rich foods like wine, cheese, and pizzas due to the inhibition of monoamine oxidase enzymes and the accumulation of tyramine.

questions.text: All the following side effects of lithium, likely to occur after 1 year of treatment except- (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tardive Dyskinesia

 

Lithium, a commonly used mood stabilizer, is associated with several side effects that may occur after prolonged treatment. However, tardive dyskinesia is not a typical side effect of lithium.

 

Tardive dyskinesia is a movement disorder characterized by repetitive, involuntary movements, usually of the face and tongue. It is more commonly associated with long-term use of antipsychotic medications, particularly first-generation antipsychotics, and not with lithium.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tremors are a common side effect of lithium that may occur after prolonged treatment.

 

Option C. Hypothyroidism is a well-known side effect of lithium, which can develop after an extended period of treatment.

 

Option D. Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is another potential side effect of lithium that may manifest after a year of treatment. Lithium can affect the kidneys' ability to concentrate urine, leading to excessive thirst and urination (polyuria).

 

Educational Objective:

 

While tremors, hypothyroidism, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus are potential side effects of lithium that may occur after a year of treatment, tardive dyskinesia is typically associated with long-term use of antipsychotic medications.

questions.text: Which of the following factors contributes least towards development of mucormycosis? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Broad spectrum antibiotics

 

While broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt the normal bacterial flora and potentially lead to fungal overgrowth, they are not a primary risk factor for mucormycosis. Antibiotics do not directly affect the fungi that cause mucormycosis and thus contribute least towards its development.

 

Mucormycosis is an opportunistic fungal infection seen in diabetics and immunocompromised patients.

 

Risk factors for the infection include the following:

 

  • Diabetic ketoacidosis

  • Long term treatment with steroids.

  • Lymphomas and leukemias

  • Immunodeficiencies

 

Clinical feature: It is an invasive fungus and leads to necrosis. It typically affects the nose , the paranasal sinuses and the orbit, leading to the production of a blackish necrotic lesion. This gave it the name of Black Fungus. It can even extend intracranially.

 

Drug of choice  for treatment of mucormycosis is  Amphotericin B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uncontrolled diabetes without ketoacidosis: While diabetic ketoacidosis is a significant risk factor, even uncontrolled diabetes without ketoacidosis can increase the risk of mucormycosis. High blood sugar levels can suppress immune function and provide a nutrient-rich environment for fungal growth.

 

Option B. Steroid treatment: Long-term steroid use is a well-known risk factor for mucormycosis because steroids suppress the immune system, making the body less capable of fighting off infections, including fungal infections like mucormycosis.

 

Option C. Neutropenia: Neutropenia, or a low neutrophil count, is a significant risk factor for mucormycosis. Neutrophils play a crucial role in the body's defense against fungal infections, and their depletion can lead to increased susceptibility to mucormycosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the listed factors, broad-spectrum antibiotics contribute the least towards the development of mucormycosis. The primary risk factors include diabetic ketoacidosis, long-term steroid treatment, neutropenia, lymphomas, leukemias, and other immunodeficiencies.

choices.text: Bipolar disorder

questions.text: Which of the following is not an off-label use of risperidone? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bipolar disorder
 

Off-label drug use refers to the prescription of a medication for a condition that is not included in its approved labeling by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

 

Risperidone is FDA-approved for the treatment of bipolar disorder. It is specifically approved for the short-term treatment of acute manic or mixed episodes associated with Bipolar I Disorder, both as monotherapy and as an adjunct to lithium or valproate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder): The use of risperidone for OCD is generally considered off-label. While antipsychotics like risperidone can be used adjunctively in treatment-resistant OCD, it's not an FDA-approved indication.

 

Option B. Dementia: Using risperidone for the treatment of behavioral symptoms in dementia is off-label. Although it's sometimes prescribed for this purpose, it's important to note that the FDA has issued a black box warning about the increased risk of death when using antipsychotic drugs in elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis.

 

Option C. PTSD: (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder): The use of risperidone in PTSD is also off-label. It has been studied and used for managing certain symptoms of PTSD, but it is not an FDA-approved indication for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risperidone is FDA-approved for the treatment of bipolar disorder, making it a labeled use. In contrast, the use of risperidone for OCD, dementia, and PTSD are off-label indications.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child has taken 10 iron tablets and presents with nausea and abdominal pain. What should be given to the child? (Fmge Jan 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Desferrioxamine.

 

  • Desferrioxamine is an antidote of iron toxicity. It is an intravenous iron-chelating compound. It can be safely administered in children. It is drug of choice for acute iron poisoning.

  • Deferipirone is oral iron chelator and is drug of choice for chronic iron poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Penicillamine: It is a copper chelating agent. It is used in Wilsonâ€™s disease.

 

Option C. Dimercaprol or British Anti Lewisite or BAL: Is used in heavy metal poisonings like mercury, arsenic, lead.

 

Option D. EDTA: Is a chelating agent which is used as an antidote for lead poisoning.

 

Educational Objective :

 

In cases of acute iron poisoning, particularly in children, Desferrioxamine is the appropriate treatment. It is an intravenous iron-chelating agent that binds free iron, facilitating its excretion and mitigating the toxic effects of the overdose. Other chelating agents like penicillamine, BAL, and EDTA are used for different types of heavy metal poisonings and are not suitable for treating iron toxicity.

choices.text: Phosphatidyl glycerol and inositol phosphate

questions.text: A patient with erectile dysfunction is given sildenafil. Which of the following mediates the action of sildenafil? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. cGMP

 

  • Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitor.
  • The corpus cavernosum produces nitric oxide during arousal that stimulates the formation of cGMP. cGMP causes relaxation of the smooth muscle of the corpus cavernosum and penile arteries, engorgement of the corpus cavernosum, and erection.
  • By inhibiting PDE 5, the hydrolysis if cGMP is prevented, thus leading to erection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. cAMP: cAMP (cyclic adenosine monophosphate) is another second messenger involved in various biological processes, but it is not the primary mediator in the mechanism of action of sildenafil for erectile dysfunction.

 

Option C. Calcium: Calcium plays a critical role in muscle contraction and various cellular functions, but it is not directly involved in the mechanism of action of sildenafil for treating erectile dysfunction.

 

Option D. Phosphatidyl glycerol and inositol phosphate: These molecules are involved in different signaling pathways, such as the phosphatidylinositol pathway, but they are not relevant to the action of sildenafil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sildenafil, a PDE5 inhibitor, enhances and prolongs erections by preventing the breakdown of cGMP, which is the primary mediator responsible for smooth muscle relaxation and increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis during arousal.

questions.text: All of the following artery demonstrates Windkessel effect except: (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Radial artery

 

Radial artery can show Windkessel effect, but among the given options, it is the most peripheral artery. As we move from center to periphery the elasticity property in the artery decreases, hence least Windkessel effect is seen in the radial artery hence it is the most appropriate answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Renal artery: The renal artery demonstrates the Windkessel effect due to its proximity to the aorta and its elastic properties.

 

Option C. Aorta: The aorta is a primary example of a vessel demonstrating the Windkessel effect.

 

Option D. Carotid artery:  The carotid artery also demonstrates the Windkessel effect due to its elastic properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WINDKESSEL VESSELS

 

Large elastic arteries contain Elastin protein â†’ elastic recoil

 

Ex: - Aorta & large arteries (e.g. Pulmonary Artery, Carotid, Renal artery)

 

  • During systole â†’ Ventricle â†’ eject blood â†’ aorta gets stretched
  • During Diastole â†’ Aortic recoil â†’ DBP
  • At old age â†’ Aortic stenosis â†’ elasticity â†’ hardening of aorta â†’ SBP â†’DBPâ†’PP

choices.text: Loss of interest in pleasurable activity

questions.text: Which of the following is considered the key symptom of depression? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Low mood

 

The most important feature of depression is low mood, also known as sadness of mood.

 

Depression is primarily a mood disorder, and while other symptoms such as sleep disturbances, guilt feelings, negative thoughts, suicidal ideations, anhedonia (loss of interest in pleasurable activities), and loss of appetite may be present, the key defining characteristic remains the persistent low mood.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Suicidal ideations are incorrect as they are not the key feature of depression. While suicidal thoughts may occur in severe cases of depression, they are not the primary defining symptom of the disorder.


Option C. Loss of interest in pleasurable activity, or anhedonia, is incorrect as it is not the most important feature of depression. Although anhedonia is a common symptom in depression, it is not the key defining characteristic of the disorder.

 

Option D. Loss of Appetite is incorrect as it is not the key feature of depression. Changes in appetite, including loss of appetite, can occur in depression but do not represent the core symptom of the disorder.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low mood, or sadness of mood, is the key defining feature of depression, as depression is primarily a mood disorder.

questions.text: A patient is showing stubbornness and frugality. According to psychosexual stages of development, the fixation is in which stage? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anal

 

According to Freud's psychosexual stages of development, which is no longer widely accepted, fixation at the anal stage can lead to certain personality traits in adulthood.

 

Individuals with anal fixation are said to be overly concerned with cleanliness, perfection, punctuality, and adherence to rules. They may exhibit stubbornness, frugality (not spending much and using minimal things), and a strong belief in their own rightness. The patient in this question displays stubbornness and frugality, which are characteristics associated with fixation at the anal stage of psychosexual development.

 

According to this theory, fixation at anal stage can cause OCD.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oral fixation is not associated with stubbornness and frugality.

 

Option C. Phallic fixation is not related to the given traits of stubbornness and frugality.

 

Option D. Genital fixation does not correspond to the characteristics mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to Freud's psychosexual stages of development, which is no longer widely accepted, fixation at the anal stage is thought to cause personality traits such as stubbornness, frugality, obsession with cleanliness, perfection, punctuality, and adherence to rules. Anal fixation is also believed to potentially lead to obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) based on this theory.

questions.text: Identify the vein from the options below that serves as a direct tributary to the inferior vena cava. (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Left inferior phrenic vein

 

 

The left inferior phrenic vein is a direct tributary of the inferior vena cava. Both the right and left inferior phrenic veins drain into the inferior vena cava.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left suprarenal vein: The left suprarenal vein does not drain directly into the inferior vena cava. Instead, it drains into the left renal vein, which then drains into the inferior vena cava.

 

Option C. Left gonadal vein: Similar to the left suprarenal vein, the left gonadal vein (whether it is the testicular vein in males or the ovarian vein in females) drains into the left renal vein before it reaches the inferior vena cava.

 

Option D. Right ascending lumbar vein: The right ascending lumbar vein is not a direct tributary of the inferior vena cava. It usually joins with the subcostal vein to form the azygos vein on the right side, which then drains into the superior vena cava.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tributaries of the inferior vena cava include veins that drain directly into it without first passing through another vein, except for the hepatic veins.

choices.text: For the prevention of typhoid most important step is immunization
Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, and personal hygiene is more important than immunization
Resistance to drugs in typhoid is less severe than that of TB
Person to person transmission is present in 10% of cases

questions.text: During a community health education session, an MBBS student is discussing the prevention of Typhoid Fever. Which of the following statements best captures the primary measures for preventing the transmission of Typhoid in the community? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Proper disposal of feces, safe water supply, personal hygiene is more important than immunization

 

  • The control of typhoid fever must be through improved sanitation and domestic/ personal hygiene.
  • Complementary approaches to prevention include immunization which is the only specific preventive measure likely to provide highest benefit for the money spent.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. For the prevention of typhoid most important step is immunization: Incorrect. While important, immunization is not the most critical step compared to improving sanitation and hygiene.

 

Option C. Resistance to drugs in typhoid is less severe than that of TB: Incorrect. This statement is unrelated to primary prevention measures for typhoid.

 

Option D. Person to person transmission is present in 10% of cases: Incorrect. Person-to-person transmission is not a significant mode of transmission for typhoid compared to the ingestion of contaminated food or water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary measures for preventing the transmission of Typhoid Fever in the community include proper disposal of feces, a safe water supply, and personal hygiene.
  • These measures are more important than immunization for controlling the spread of the disease.

choices.text: Rinneâ€™s test positive , Weberâ€™s test lateralized to left ear
Rinneâ€™s test positive , Weberâ€™s test lateralized to right ear
Rinneâ€™s test negative , Weberâ€™s test lateralized to left ear
Rinneâ€™s test negative , Weberâ€™s test lateralized to right ear

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with bilateral hearing loss with worsened right ear hearing loss. On examination, the doctor diagnose Otosclerosis and recommends stapedectomy as a final resort to the problem. What would be the findings of tuning fork tests based on which the doctor has recommended stapedectomy? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Rinneâ€™s test negative, Weberâ€™s test lateralized to right ear

 

  • Rinneâ€™s test negative: Typical of otosclerosis, indicating conductive hearing loss where BC > AC.
  • Weberâ€™s test lateralized to right ear: Indicates that the sound is heard better in the ear with more conductive loss, which matches otosclerosis more severely affecting the right ear.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rinneâ€™s test positive, Weberâ€™s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinneâ€™s test positive: Indicates that air conduction (AC) is better than bone conduction (BC), which is a normal finding and typically not expected in conductive hearing loss like otosclerosis.
  • Weberâ€™s test lateralized to left ear: In a case of unilateral or asymmetric hearing loss, Weber's test lateralizes to the better hearing ear in sensorineural hearing loss and to the poorer ear in conductive hearing loss. This pattern does not fit otosclerosis affecting the right ear more severely.

 

Option B. Rinneâ€™s test positive, Weberâ€™s test lateralized to right ear:

 

  • Rinneâ€™s test positive: Again, indicates normal AC > BC, not typical for otosclerosis.
  • Weberâ€™s test lateralized to right ear: Would suggest either a sensorineural hearing loss on the left ear or less likely conductive loss on the right, which doesnâ€™t match typical otosclerosis findings.

 

Option C. Rinneâ€™s test negative, Weberâ€™s test lateralized to left ear:

 

  • Rinneâ€™s test negative: Indicates that BC > AC, suggesting conductive hearing loss, typical of otosclerosis.
  • Weberâ€™s test lateralized to left ear: Would imply the left ear is either better or has conductive loss, not aligning with greater hearing loss in the right ear due to otosclerosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The combination of a negative Rinne test and Weber test lateralizing to the ear with more hearing loss is indicative of conductive hearing loss in that ear. In otosclerosis, the ossification of the stapes leads to mechanical dysfunction, preventing effective sound transmission, hence a stapedectomy might be recommended to mechanically bypass the ossified stapes and improve hearing.

questions.text:
Cochlear implantation is not indicated in which of the following conditions? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Otosclerosis
  2. Congenital hearing loss
  3. Fixed malleus
  4. Ototoxicity induced hearing loss
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 3

 

Cochlear implantation is not indicated in otosclerosis and fixed malleus because these are conductive hearing loss conditions that can be effectively treated with surgical correction. Cochlear implants are designed specifically for sensorineural hearing loss where the cochlear hair cells are damaged but the auditory nerve remains intact.

 

1. Otosclerosis: Otosclerosis involves abnormal bone growth around the stapes footplate, causing fixation and conductive hearing loss. This condition is best treated with stapedectomy or stapedotomy, which directly addresses the mechanical problem by replacing or bypassing the fixed stapes. Success rates for stapedectomy exceed 90% for hearing improvement.

 

3. Fixed malleus: Fixed malleus also causes conductive hearing loss due to mechanical fixation of the ossicular chain. This condition is treated with ossiculoplasty or malleus fixation release procedures that restore normal sound transmission through the middle ear. These surgical interventions directly correct the underlying mechanical problem and can restore near-normal hearing.

 

Incorrect Options:

 

2. Congenital hearing loss: Cochlear implant IS indicated here. This is actually a major indication for cochlear implantation, especially for pre-lingual deaf children (age limit 6 years) where hearing aid trial for 6 months shows no improvement in speech development.

 

4. Ototoxicity induced hearing loss: Cochlear implant IS indicated here. Ototoxic drugs like aminoglycosides (neomycin, gentamicin), chemotherapy agents (cisplatin, carboplatin), diuretics (furosemide, bumetanide), and antimalarials (quinine, chloroquine) cause permanent damage to outer hair cells in the cochlea. When this damage is severe and irreversible, cochlear implantation is the treatment of choice.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Cochlear implants are contraindicated in middle ear pathologies that can be surgically corrected.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman presents to your clinic with a concern about a hypopigmented patch on her forearm. She has noticed reduced sensation over the patch. During the physical examination, you also notice thickening of some peripheral nerves. Which of the following combinations of criteria would be appropriate for diagnosing Leprosy in suspected cases? [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. Hypopigmented skin lesions with sensory deficit
  2. Peripheral nerve thickening with sensory loss and muscle weakening
  3. Family history of leprosy
  4. Slit skin smears
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 4

 

To diagnose Leprosy, at least one of the following cardinal signs must be present:

 

1. Hypopigmented or reddish skin lesions with definite sensory deficit: This is a primary indicator of Leprosy. The presence of sensory deficits in these lesions points to the nerve involvement characteristic of the disease.

 

2. Peripheral nerve involvement - thickening with sensory loss and muscle weakening/paralysis: Thickening of peripheral nerves, combined with sensory loss and muscle weakening or paralysis, is another key indicator of Leprosy. These clinical signs suggest the spread of the infection to peripheral nerves.

 

4. Demonstration of M. leprae in lesions (Slit skin smears): This involves laboratory confirmation through slit skin smears showing the presence of Mycobacterium leprae. It is a definitive diagnostic method for Leprosy.

 

Other Options:

 

3. family history of leprosy is not considered one of the cardinal signs necessary for diagnosis. It is more relevant in understanding the epidemiological context rather than serving as a primary diagnostic criterion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

At least one of the following cardinal signs must be present to diagnose Leprosy

 

  1. Hypopigmented or reddish skin lesions with definite sensory deficit
  2. Peripheral nerve involvement - thickening with sensory loss and muscle weakening/paralysis
  3. Demonstration of M. leprae in lesions (Slit skin smears)

questions.text:
A woman has vomiting whenever she eats spicy food. Arrange the sequence of events during vomiting? (INICET MAY 2022)

 

  1. LES is open and UES is closed.
  2. Strong contractions in the stomach.
  3. Inspiration against a closed glottis.
  4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter.
  5. LES opens and UES opens.
  6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine.
     

LES: Lower esophageal sphincter

 

UES: Upper esophageal sphincter
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 6, 4, 2, 3, 1, 5

 

The correct sequence of events during vomiting is:

 

6. Reverse peristalsis in the small intestine: This begins the vomiting process, moving contents from the ileum towards the stomach.

 

4. Relaxation of the pyloric sphincter: This allows the contents to move from the small intestine into the stomach.

 

2. Strong contractions in the stomach: These contractions help to force the stomach contents upwards.

 

3. Inspiration against a closed glottis: This involves taking a deep breath with the glottis closed, increasing intra-abdominal pressure.

 

1. LES is open and UES is closed: Initially, the LES opens to allow the contents to move into the esophagus, while the UES remains closed.

 

5. LES opens and UES opens: Finally, both sphincters open to allow the contents to be expelled through the mouth.

 

Act of vomiting involves series of movements that takes place in GI tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sequence of events in act of vomiting:

 

  1. Beginning of antiperistalsis, which runs from ileum towards the mouth through the intestine, pushing the intestinal contents into the stomach within few minutes. Velocity of the antiperistalsis is about 2 to 3 cm/second
  2. Deep inspiration followed by temporary cessation of breathing
  3. Closure of glottis
  4. Upward and forward movement of larynx and hyoid bone
  5. Elevation of soft palate
  6. Contraction of diaphragm and abdominal muscles with a characteristic jerk, resulting in elevation of intra-abdominal pressure
  7. Compression of the stomach between diaphragm and abdominal wall leading to rise in intragastric pressure
  8. Simultaneous relaxation of lower esophageal sphincter, esophagus and upper esophageal sphincter
  9. Forceful expulsion of gastric contents (vomitus) through esophagus, pharynx and mouth.

questions.text: Identify the thalamic nucleus that receives efferent fibers from the structure indicated by the arrow in the image. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anterior

 

 

 

The image shows a coronal section of the brain with the indicated structure being the fornix. The fornix is a C-shaped bundle of nerve fibers in the brain that acts as a major output tract of the hippocampus. It is involved in the Papez circuit, which plays a key role in the control of memory functions.

 

  • Anterior Nucleus of the Thalamus: The fornix carries signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus. The anterior nucleus of the thalamus is an integral part of the Papez circuit, involved in emotional and memory processing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lateral: The lateral nuclei of the thalamus are involved in sensory relay and integration but are not the primary efferent targets of the fornix.

 

Option C. Ventro-postero-lateral: This nucleus is involved in the relay of sensory information from the body to the brain but is not connected to the fornix.

 

Option D. Pulvinar: The pulvinar nucleus is involved in visual processing and attention, not directly associated with the fornix.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The fornix transmits signals from the hippocampus to the mammillary bodies, which then project to the anterior nucleus of the thalamus, playing a crucial role in memory processing within the Papez circuit.

questions.text: Match the following drugs in column A to their site of action in column B?(INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A-4, B-1, C-3, D-2


The correct match is as follows:

 

 

  • Acetazolamide is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor that acts at the proximal convoluted tubules.
  • Torsemide is a loop diuretic that acts by inhibiting Na+-K+-2Cl channel at the thick ascending limb of the Loop of Henle.
  • Chlorthalidone, a thiazide-like diuretic, inhibits the Na-CI symporter in the distal convoluted tubule.
  • Vasopressin, or ADH, is secreted by the posterior pituitary and mainly acts on the collecting duct, and increases the reabsorption of free water.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acetazolamide acts on the proximal convoluted tubule, Torsemide on the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle, Chlorothiazide on the distal convoluted tubule, and Vasopressin on the collecting duct.

choices.text: It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases
It shows Ad type of curve

questions.text: A patient has otitis media with effusion. Which of the following is wrong?  (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It shows Ad type of curve

 

Otitis media with effusion (OME) is a condition characterized by the presence of fluid in the middle ear without signs or symptoms of acute ear infection. The incorrect statement regarding it is, It shows Ad type of curve. This statement is incorrect. OME typically shows a B type of tympanogram curve. A B type curve indicates the presence of middle ear fluid. An Ad type curve is associated with ossicular discontinuity, which is not related to OME.

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is bilateral: Can be true but not mandatory; OME can be unilateral or bilateral.

 

Option B. It undergoes spontaneous resolution after cold decreases: True, as the condition often resolves with the resolution of the underlying URTI.

 

Option C. It is associated with cold: True, as URTI and colds can lead to Eustachian tube dysfunction and subsequent fluid accumulation in the middle ear.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Otitis media with effusion shows a B type of tympanogram curve, not an Ad type curve.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway:(INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2-1-3-4-5

 

The correct sequence of the auditory pathway is spiral ganglion - cochlear nucleus - superior olivary nucleus - inferior colliculus - medial geniculate body.

 

2. Spiral Ganglion : The spiral ganglion is situated in Rosenthal's canal and contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve, which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

 

1. Cochlear Nucleus : The cochlear nerve fibers synapse in the cochlear nuclei located in the brainstem.

 

3. Superior Olivary Nucleus : After the cochlear nucleus, the pathway proceeds to the superior olivary nucleus.

 

4. Inferior Colliculus : From the superior olivary nucleus, the auditory signals travel to the inferior colliculus in the midbrain.

 

5. Medial Geniculate Body : The signals are then relayed to the medial geniculate body of the thalamus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA).

 

  1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
  2. Cochlear Nucleus
  3. Superior Olivary nucleus
  4. Lateral lemniscus
  5. Inferior colliculus
  6. Medial geniculate body
  7. Auditory cortex

questions.text: Carhart notch is seen in: (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Otosclerosis

 

Carhart's notch is a characteristic audiometric finding in otosclerosis where there is a dip in bone conduction at 2000 Hz (2 kHz) on pure tone audiometry. In otosclerosis, there is irregular spongy bone deposition in the anterior part of footplate and adjacent oval window (fissula ante fenestram), which impedes sound conduction and causes conductive hearing loss. When plotting an audiogram, the bone conduction curve shows this specific notch or dip at 2000 Hz, while the air conduction curve remains affected throughout, showing the conductive hearing loss pattern.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sudden SNHL: Sudden sensorineural hearing loss shows a sudden drop in both air and bone conduction curves across all frequencies without any specific notch pattern at 2000 Hz.

 

Option C. Meniere's disease: In Meniere's disease, the audiogram typically shows a low-frequency sensorineural hearing loss with an up-sloping curve. There is no specific notch at 2000 Hz.

 

 

Option D. Acoustic neuroma: Acoustic neuroma typically shows a trough-shaped or cookie-bite audiogram pattern affecting the middle frequencies, but does not show the specific Carhart's notch at 2000 Hz.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carhart's notch is a characteristic dip at 2000 Hz on the bone conduction curve in pure tone audiometry, specifically seen in otosclerosis.

 

Important points to remember on otoselerosis:

 

  • Most common site - Fissula ante fenestrum
  • Most common type- Stapedial
  • Other 2 type -Cochlear, Histologic
  • Clinical presentation - Hearing impairment
  • Paracusis willisii (hears better in noisy surroundngs)
  • Otoscopy - Intract tympanic membrane
  • Schwarts sign - Seen in active lesions only, reddish hue seen on promontory through intact TM
  • Tunning fork tests - Rinne negative, Weber to poorer ear â†’ conductive loss
  • Pure tone audiometry -Dip at 2000Hz on BC curve (Carhart's notch)
  • Treatment of choice - Surgery (Stapedotomy > Stapedectomy)
  • Other treatments - NaF, Hearing aid for those not fit for surgery.

questions.text: A patient from Bihar was admitted with massive splenomegaly, on-off fever, anemia, and features of leishmaniasis. The vector causing it is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Phlebotomus

 

Leishmaniasis is a parasitic disease caused by the Leishmania species and transmitted by the bite of infected sandflies. In this case, the patient presents with massive splenomegaly, fever, anemia, and other features suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), which is endemic in regions like Bihar, India. The vector responsible for transmitting Leishmania is the Phlebotomus species, commonly known as sandflies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rat fly: Rat flies are not vectors for Leishmania. They are typically associated with the spread of different diseases, like murine typhus, but not leishmaniasis.

 

Option C. Chrysops fly: Chrysops flies are known as deer flies and are vectors for diseases like Loiasis but are not involved in the transmission of Leishmania.

 

Option D. Black fly: Black flies are vectors for Onchocerciasis (river blindness) and have no role in the transmission of Leishmania.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Leishmaniasis, particularly visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar), is transmitted by the Phlebotomus species, also known as sandflies.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding Vacuum-Assisted Closure (VAC) dressing are correct? (INICET MAY 2025)

 

  1. Reduces bacterial load 
  2. Maximum pressure is -125mm of Hg 
  3. Promotes granulation tissue 
  4. Reduces size of wound
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3 and 4

 

VAC (Vacuum Assisted Closure) dressing, also known as Negative Pressure Wound Therapy (NPWT), is a therapeutic technique that uses controlled negative pressure to promote wound healing. All four statements about VAC dressing are correct.

 

1. Reduces bacterial load 

 

  • VAC therapy uses controlled negative pressure to draw out excess fluid and infectious materials from the wound bed.
  • It decreases local bacterial colonization, helps prevent infection, and supports a cleaner wound environment.
  • This effect enhances the wound's ability to heal efficiently.

 

2.  Maximum pressure is -125 mmHg 

 

  • The standard therapeutic range for VAC dressing is between -75 mmHg to -125 mmHg.
  • -125 mmHg is considered the maximum standard pressure used for optimal clinical benefit.
  • Lower pressures may be used in certain cases, but -125 mmHg is the commonly applied maximum.

 

3.  Promotes granulation tissue 

 

  • The negative pressure improves blood perfusion and oxygen delivery to the wound, encouraging angiogenesis.
  • It promotes the formation of healthy granulation tissue, which is essential for wound healing and epithelialization.

 

4. Reduces size of wound 

 

  • The vacuum effect draws the edges of the wound inward through mechanical approximation, thereby reducing wound dimensions.
  • Over time, this leads to a noticeable decrease in wound size, making it easier to manage and close.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VAC therapy at -100 to -125 mmHg reduces bacterial load through continuous drainage, promotes granulation tissue by improving vascularity and removing MMPs, and mechanically approximates wound edges to reduce wound size.

questions.text: After parotid surgery, the patient is found to have weakness of the lower lip on the ipsilateral side. Which of these injuries is likely to produce this? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cervical branch of facial nerve

 

In this scenario, the patient has undergone parotid surgery and subsequently developed weakness of the lower lip on the same side as the surgery (ipsilateral). This kind of symptom indicates a nerve injury.

 

  • Facial Nerve Branches: The facial nerve (cranial nerve VII) is responsible for motor control of the muscles of facial expression. It divides into several branches after it exits the stylomastoid foramen, including the temporal, zygomatic, buccal, mandibular (marginal mandibular), and cervical branches.
  • Cervical Branch: The cervical branch of the facial nerve, along with the marginal mandibular branch, supplies the muscles of the lower face, including those involved in the movement of the lower lip. An injury to the cervical branch could result in weakness of the lower lip, which is consistent with the patient's presentation.
  • Marginal Mandibular Branch: Although the marginal mandibular branch is primarily responsible for the lower lip, in cases where this specific branch is not listed as an option, the cervical branch is the closest and most accurate choice because it is part of the lower division of the facial nerve that supplies the lower lip muscles.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Main trunk of the facial nerve: Injury to the main trunk of the facial nerve would likely cause more extensive symptoms, including the inability to close the eye (Bell's phenomenon), loss of forehead wrinkling, and other signs of lower motor neuron facial paralysis, which are not mentioned in this case. Therefore, this option is less likely.

 

Option B. Temporal branch of the facial nerve: The temporal branch of the facial nerve innervates muscles in the upper face, such as those involved in raising the eyebrows and closing the eyelids. It does not affect the lower lip, making this option incorrect.

 

Option D. Parotid duct: Injury to the parotid duct would result in issues related to salivation, such as a salivary fistula, but it would not cause motor weakness of the lower lip. This option is also incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Weakness of the lower lip after parotid surgery is most likely due to injury to the cervical branch of the facial nerve. The marginal mandibular branch is the most specific, but if not listed, the cervical branch is the closest correct option

questions.text: Which of the following is best for the malaria species identification? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thin smear with Giemsa

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for identifying malaria species. This is because thin smears allow for detailed observation of the morphological characteristics of the malaria parasites within red blood cells. The Giemsa stain helps to highlight these features clearly, enabling the identification of the different Plasmodium species based on their unique structures.

 

Thin Smear Usage: Thin smears are used for speciation as they provide a detailed view of the parasites' morphology. This allows for differentiation among the four Plasmodium species (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale) by examining the shapes and forms of the parasites within the red blood cells. Thin smears enable the visualization of specific features such as the ring form, amoeboid form, and schizonts in P. vivax, as well as multiple rings and banana-shaped gametocytes in P. falciparum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Thick smear with Giemsa: Thick smears are primarily used for quantification of parasites and for genus identification but are not ideal for speciation because the density of the sample can obscure detailed morphological features.

 

Option C. Thin smear with acridine orange: Acridine orange is a fluorescent stain used for rapid screening but is less effective than Giemsa for detailed species identification. It is better suited for initial diagnosis rather than detailed speciation.

 

Option D. QBC (Quantitative Buffy Coat): QBC is a method used for detecting malaria parasites based on fluorescence microscopy. While it is rapid and sensitive, it does not provide detailed morphological information necessary for accurate species identification.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man has been diagnosed with tuberculosis. As part of his treatment plan, he is prescribed a combination of antitubercular drugs. While counseling him on the drug regimen, you explain the mechanisms of action of each drug. Which of the following combinations of statements accurately describe the mechanisms of some of the drugs used in treating tuberculosis? [INICET NOV 2022]

 

  1. Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis
  2. Pyrazinamide is an enzyme inducer
  3. Rifampicin is used only in the treatment of tuberculosis
  4. Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) 1, 4

 

1. lsoniazid - INH is activated by catalase peroxidase (formed by Kat G) enzyme of mycobacteria. It acts by inhibiting the formation of mycolic acid.

 

4. Bedaquiline - Act by inhibiting ATP synthase enzyme, can result in QT prolongation

 

Other Options:

 

2. Pyrazinamide - Possess the best sterilizing activity (can kill slow growing bacteria) and makes the medium sterile. Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation in Mycobacterium tuberculosis. It is not an enzyme inducer.

 

3. Rifampicin - Act by inhibiting RNA polymerase of mycobacteria by binding to its Î²-subunit. It thus inhibits transcription. Uses of Rifampicin are:

 

  • Tuberculosis
  • Leprosy
  • DOC for Brucella (doxycycline + rifampicin)
  • Effective against Gram positive bacteria (including MRSA)
  • Effective against Gram negative bacteria (including Pseudomonas)
  • It was used for prophylaxis of meningococcus meningitis

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isoniazid inhibits mycolic acid synthesis.
  • Bedaquiline inhibits ATP synthase enzyme.
  • Pyrazinamide inhibits trans-translation
  • Rifampicin inhibit RNA polymerase

questions.text: An individual went to the US and developed an infection. LPCB mount showed the following. Identify the cause. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histoplasma capsulatum


The LPCB (Lactophenol Cotton Blue) mount in the image shows structures with a tuberculate appearance, which are characteristic of the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum. Histoplasma capsulatum is a dimorphic fungus commonly found in certain areas of the United States, especially in the Ohio and Mississippi River valleys. The tuberculate macroconidia seen on LPCB mounts are a diagnostic feature of Histoplasma, and this form helps differentiate it from other fungal infections.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Coccidioides immitis: Coccidioides immitis typically presents with spherules containing endospores in tissue, not the tuberculate structures seen in this LPCB mount. Coccidioides is known for causing coccidioidomycosis (Valley Fever), primarily seen in arid regions like the southwestern US.

 

Option B. Blastomyces dermatitidis: Blastomyces dermatitidis shows a broad-based budding yeast form in tissues, and does not present with tuberculate structures. A classic LPCB mount of Blastomyces would show the figure-of-eight appearance of budding yeast cells, which is not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:


Histoplasma capsulatum is identified by its distinctive tuberculate macroconidia on LPCB mounts, which is a key feature to recognize this dimorphic fungus, especially in infections contracted in the United States.

choices.text: Muscle fasciculations

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency room after poisoning with an unknown substance. Muscarinic poisoning was suspected and he was treated for the same. What is the possible presenting feature which led to the diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bradycardia
 

The types of Muscarinic receptors and their actions are as follows:

 

  • M1 – They increase the acid secretion in the stomach
  • M2 – They are present in the heart and lead to a decrease in heart rate (Bradycardia) and cause slowing of conduction in the AV node.
  • M3 – They are present in the respiratory tract and cause bronchoconstriction. They are also present in the urinary bladder, where they help in urination by bringing about contraction of the bladder. In the glands, these receptors help in secretion. In the eyes it leads to miosis.

 

Bradycardia is the possible presenting feature which led to the diagnosis of muscarinic poisoning in this case. Muscarinic poisoning occurs due to the consumption of poisonous mushroom-like Inocybe. Muscarinic symptoms appear within an hour of eating the mushroom. These symptoms (along with nicotinic symptoms) can also be seen in organophosphate poisoning. Atropine is used for the management of muscarinic poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mydriasis: This refers to pupil dilation, which is typically associated with sympathetic stimulation or anticholinergic effects, not muscarinic poisoning.

 

Option B. Diuresis: This refers to increased urine production, which is not a direct effect of muscarinic poisoning. Muscarinic activation actually increases bladder contraction, promoting urination.

 

Option C. Muscle fasciculations: These are more associated with nicotinic receptor activation, not muscarinic receptor activation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bradycardia is a key presenting feature that can lead to the diagnosis of muscarinic poisoning. Muscarinic receptors, particularly M2 receptors in the heart, mediate a decrease in heart rate. Atropine is used to manage muscarinic poisoning by blocking acetylcholine's action on these receptors.

choices.text: ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave
Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision
Night blindness is a late feature

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect about Retinitis Pigmentosa? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Night blindness is a late feature

 

Retinitis Pigmentosa (RP) is a group of hereditary disorders that cause progressive degeneration of the retina, specifically affecting the photoreceptors (rods and cones).

 

Night blindness is a late feature: This is incorrect. Night blindness (nyctalopia) is an early feature of RP. Patients often present with difficulties in dark adaptation and night vision long before significant peripheral vision loss occurs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ERG shows decreased amplitude of a and b wave: Electroretinography (ERG) in RP patients shows decreased amplitude of both the a wave (originating from rods and cones) and the b wave (originating from bipolar cells).

 

Option B. Rod dystrophy > Cone dystrophy: RP typically starts with rod dysfunction, which later involves the cones.

 

Option C. Late presentation is loss of peripheral vision: RP usually presents with mid-peripheral vision loss, which progresses to peripheral vision loss and eventually central vision loss, leading to tunnel vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Night blindness is an early feature of Retinitis Pigmentosa, not a late one. The initial symptoms typically include difficulties with night vision.

questions.text: Which of these is not a component/adjunct of the primary survey in trauma? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) CECT

 

Primary survey adjuncts include:

 

  • Chest X-ray
  • Pelvic X-ray
  • eFAST (Extended Focused Assessment with Sonography in Trauma)
  • ECG
  • Pulse oximetry
  • Arterial blood gas
  • Urinary catheter
  • Nasogastric tube
  • CECT is part of secondary survey, performed only in hemodynamically stable patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chest X-ray:

 

  • Essential adjunct to primary survey
  • Quickly identifies life-threatening conditions like pneumothorax, hemothorax

 

Option B. Pelvic X-ray:

 

  • Important adjunct in primary survey
  • Identifies pelvic fractures which can cause major hemorrhage
  • Guides immediate management decisions

 

Option C. Extended FAST :

 

  • Critical bedside tool in primary survey
  • Rapidly identifies free fluid in abdomen/chest
  • Particularly valuable in unstable patients

 

Educational Objective: 

 

CECT is not a component of primary survey - it belongs to secondary survey and is performed only in hemodynamically stable patients.

questions.text:
Which of the following muscles are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve? (INICET Nov 2023)

 

  1. Abductor hallucis
  2. Flexor digitorum accessorius
  3. Flexor hallucis brevis
  4. First lumbrical
  5. First interossei
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 2 and 5

 

 

 

The lateral plantar nerve is a branch of the tibial nerve, which innervates various muscles in the sole of the foot. It divides into superficial and deep branches, each supplying specific muscles.

 

  • Flexor Digitorum Accessorius : This muscle assists in the flexion of the toes and is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.
  • First Interossei: The interossei muscles, which include the dorsal and plantar interossei, are responsible for abduction and adduction of the toes. The first interossei is supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

1. Abductor hallucis: This muscle is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, not the lateral plantar nerve.

 

3. Flexor hallucis brevis: This muscle is also supplied by the medial plantar nerve.

 

4. First lumbrical: The first lumbrical is supplied by the medial plantar nerve, whereas the second, third, and fourth lumbricals are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The lateral plantar nerve supplies the flexor digitorum accessorius (quadratus plantae) and the first interossei muscles in the foot.

questions.text: A 1-year-old child who was born premature at 34 weeks POG weighing 1400 gms presents with leukocoria. On CT, intraocular calcification is seen. What is the most probable diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Retinoblastoma

 

Explanation:

 

While the history of prematurity (34 weeks) and low birth weight (1400g) might suggest ROP, the presence of intraocular calcification on CT scan is pathognomonic for retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy of childhood, and it is the only condition among the given options that shows intraocular calcification. This calcification can be detected on CT scan, though CT is generally avoided due to radiation exposure risks. The preferred imaging modalities are ultrasound B-scan and contrast-enhanced MRI.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ROP (Retinopathy of Prematurity): While the premature birth and low birth weight are risk factors for ROP, it does not present with intraocular calcification. ROP occurs in newborns <34 weeks or <2.0 kg birth weight and presents with abnormal vessel development.

 

Option B. Congenital Cataract: This presents as leukocoria but does not show intraocular calcification. It is an opacity of the natural lens that is present at birth.

 

Option D. Coat's Disease: While this can present with leukocoria, it is characterized by retinal telangiectasia and exudation without calcification. It typically affects young males and is usually unilateral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraocular calcification seen on imaging in a child with leukocoria is pathognomonic for retinoblastoma, regardless of other clinical factors like prematurity.

choices.text: If replacement feeding, the neonate should be tested for HIV, if negative, ART is not required.
In exclusive breastfeeding, give nevirapine for 6 months only when baby is positive
If replacement feeding, the neonate need not receive nevirapine if HIV negative
If exclusive replacement feeding, give nevirapine for 6 weeks, even if the baby is negative

questions.text: A pediatrician is providing counselling to a pregnant woman who is HIV positive about postnatal care for her soon-to-be-born child. Which of the following statements best captures the recommended management for an infant born to a mother with HIV regarding antiretroviral treatment (ART)? [INICET MAY 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) If exclusive replacement feeding, give nevirapine for 6 weeks, even if the baby is negative

 

The baby should be given prophylaxis irrespective of feeding status and HIV status at birth.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. If replacement feeding, the neonate should be tested for HIV, if negative, ART is not required: Incorrect. Prophylaxis with nevirapine should still be given for 6 weeks regardless of HIV status.

 

Option B. In exclusive breastfeeding, give nevirapine for 6 months only when baby is positive: Incorrect. Nevirapine is given as prophylaxis irrespective of the infant's HIV status.

 

Option C. If replacement feeding, the neonate need not receive nevirapine if HIV negative: Incorrect. Prophylaxis should still be provided for 6 weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Infants of HIV-positive mothers on exclusive replacement feeding get 6-week nevirapine, regardless of their HIV status.

questions.text: A patient is able to perceive color, texture, and shape but is unable to recognize objects. Which cortical area is most likely affected? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Occipital area

 

 

The patientâ€™s symptoms indicate a condition known as visual agnosia, where there is an inability to recognize objects despite having intact vision for color, texture, and shape. This suggests that the primary visual cortex (area 17) is functioning properly, but the secondary visual processing areas (areas 18 and 19) are affected.

 

  • Occipital Area: The occipital lobe, specifically Brodmann areas 18 and 19, are responsible for the higher-order processing of visual information. Lesions in these areas can result in visual agnosia, where the patient can see but cannot interpret or recognize visual stimuli.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial parietal area: The medial parietal area is not primarily  involved in visual recognition.

 

Option B. Lateral parietal area: The lateral parietal area is not involved in the direct processing of visual information.

 

Option C. Infra temporal area: The infra temporal area is not involved in the direct processing of visual information.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lesions in the secondary visual processing areas (areas 18 and 19) of the occipital lobe can result in visual agnosia, where the patient can see but cannot identify objects.

questions.text: Which type of PCR is suitable for identifying multiple causative agents? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Multiplex PCR    

 

Multiplex PCR is a technique that allows the simultaneous amplification of multiple target sequences in a single PCR reaction. This makes it particularly useful for identifying multiple causative agents in a single test, such as when diagnosing conditions like diarrhea that can be caused by a variety of pathogens including viruses, bacteria, and fungi. Multiplex PCR uses multiple sets of primers in a single reaction mixture, each specific for a different target, allowing the detection of multiple organisms in one run.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nested PCR: This technique is designed to increase the specificity of PCR by using two sets of primers in two successive runs, but it is not intended for simultaneous detection of multiple pathogens. It is primarily used to reduce non-specific binding and enhance detection sensitivity for a specific target.

 

Option B. Real-time PCR: While real-time PCR can quantify DNA or RNA targets and is highly sensitive, it typically amplifies one target per reaction or a few targets in separate reactions rather than multiple agents in a single test.

 

Option C. Conventional PCR: This method involves amplifying a single DNA target per reaction and is not designed to handle multiple targets simultaneously, making it less suitable for identifying multiple causative agents.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Multiplex PCR is the best choice for identifying multiple causative agents in a single test, making it efficient and comprehensive for diagnosing conditions caused by various pathogens.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with an ulcerative lesion noted near the nose/medical canthus. What is the probable diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Basal cell carcinoma 

 

  • The patient's presentation with an ulcerative lesion near the nose/medial canthus with rolled out edges is a basal cell carcinoma. 

 

This is the most common type of skin cancer, often appearing in sun-exposed areas such as the face. BCC frequently presents as a pearly bump with telangiectatic vessels or as a flat, flesh-colored or brown scar-like lesion. Ulceration is common in neglected or advanced BCC, particularly near critical areas like the nose and eyes, where it can cause significant local destruction. Given its common presentation and the description provided, BCC is a very likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lentigo Maligna Melanoma: This is a type of melanoma that typically occurs on sun-exposed areas of the skin, particularly the face and the arms, in older adults. It begins as a patch that darkens, enlarges, and sometimes becomes nodular, indicating progression to melanoma. It's less common for lentigo maligna to present initially as an ulcerative lesion, making this a less likely diagnosis.

 

Option C. Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC): SCC is a type of skin cancer that can also appear on sun-exposed skin and may develop from a pre-existing actinic keratosis. It can be more aggressive than BCC and typically presents as a thick, rough, scaly patch that can bleed if bumped. It can ulcerate but often has a more rapid growth compared to BCC.

 

Option D. Nevus: A nevus is a common skin growth (mole), which can be present from birth or appear during childhood or young adulthood. While most nevi are benign, changes in their appearance, such as ulceration, require evaluation to rule out malignant transformation, such as into melanoma.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Given the description of an ulcerative lesion near critical areas like the nose and medial canthus, Basal Cell Carcinoma is the most probable diagnosis due to its frequent occurrence in these regions and its tendency to ulcerate. Treatment typically involves surgical excision, and in some cases, topical or systemic therapy may be considered.

questions.text: Function of IL-8 is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  A) Chemotaxis

 

Interleukin-8 (IL-8) is a cytokine that primarily functions as a chemokine. It plays a crucial role in the immune response by attracting and activating neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation through chemotaxis. This movement of neutrophils to the affected area helps in fighting infections effectively, as they are key cells in the innate immune response.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fever: Fever is primarily induced by cytokines such as IL-1, IL-6, and TNF-alpha, not IL-8. These cytokines act on the hypothalamus to increase body temperature, which is a part of the systemic inflammatory response.

 

Option C. Lymphocyte proliferation: Lymphocyte proliferation is mainly associated with cytokines such as IL-2, which stimulates the growth of T cells. IL-8 does not play a direct role in lymphocyte proliferation.

 

Option D. TH1 activation: TH1 activation is driven by cytokines like IL-12 and IFN-gamma, which promote the differentiation of T-helper cells into the TH1 subtype. IL-8 is not involved in this process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary function of IL-8 is to induce chemotaxis, particularly attracting neutrophils to sites of infection or inflammation.

choices.text: Half-life doubles and plasma concentration remains the same
Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles
Half-life and plasma concentration remains the same
Half-life and plasma concentration doubles

questions.text: What would happen to the half-life and plasma concentration of a drug which follows first-order kinetics, if the dose is doubled? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles
 

In case of drugs following 1st order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is eliminated in a given time. Therefore, the half-life of the drug remains constant and the Clearance also remains constant.

 

Key points regarding first-order kinetics:

 

  • Half-life remains constant: The half-life of the drug does not change with the dose. It remains constant because the fraction of the drug eliminated per unit time is constant.
  • Clearance remains constant: The clearance, which is the volume of plasma from which the drug is completely removed per unit time, remains constant.
  • Plasma concentration: When the dose is doubled, the plasma concentration of the drug also doubles because the rate of elimination is proportional to the concentration of the drug in the plasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For drugs following first-order kinetics, The rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional its plasma concentration. So, when the dose is doubled for a drug following first order kinetics, the plasma concentration is also doubled.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from Mumbai presents to a clinic with fatigue and weakness. His family has a history of chronic diseases, but he himself has been asymptomatic until recently. The physician explains the different stages of disease progression and the interventions required. Which of the following best matches the stages with their relevant descriptions? [INICET NOV 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 1-d, 2-b, 3-a, 4-c

 

  • Natural history of disease refers to the progression of a disease in an individual over time, in the absence of treatment. It has two phases, a period of pre-pathogenesis and a period of pathogenesis.

 

 

  • The period of pre-pathogenesis is before the onset of disease in humans.
  • An interaction between the agent, host and the environment occurs in this phase before the pathogenesis.
  • It starts with appropriate exposure to or accumulation of factors sufficient for the disease process to begin in a susceptible host.
  • The exposure is a microorganism in an infectious disease. For lung cancer, it is any factor that initiates the process, such as asbestos fibres or components in tobacco smoke.
  • Primary prevention (health promotion and specific protection) is applicable in this period.
  • The period of pathogenesis starts after the disease process has been triggered and pathological changes occur without the individual being aware of it.
  • It begins with the entry of the organism till recovery, death, or disability.
  • The subclinical or asymptomatic period between exposure and onset of symptoms is called the incubation period for infectious diseases, and the latency period for chronic diseases.
  • The onset of clinical symptoms is the beginning of the clinical stage of the disease.
  • Secondary (halting of the disease process) and tertiary prevention (measures to limit disability) are applicable in this period.
  • Rehabilitation has been defined as the use of medical, social, educational, and vocational measures for training the individual to the highest possible level of functional ability.
  • It is a part of tertiary prevention like providing callipers for walking patients and arranging schooling after being affected by polio.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is a novel anti-depressant? (INICET Nov 2021
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vilazodone

 

Vilazodone is a Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitor as well as a 5HT1A receptor partial agonist. It is a new antidepressant. It does not have the side effect of erectile dysfunction.

 

Vortioxetine is another example of a novel antidepressant, that apart from being a SSRI, acts on multiple other receptors of serotonin.

 

Other Options:

 

Lurasidone, Asenapine and Pimavanserin are examples of atypical antipsychotics.

 

Option A. Lurasidone: This is an atypical antipsychotic, primarily used in the treatment of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. While it can be used to treat depressive episodes in bipolar disorder, it is not primarily categorized as an antidepressant.

 

Option C. Asenapine: Asenapine is an atypical antipsychotic used to treat schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. It is not classified as an antidepressant.

 

Option D. Pimavanserin: This is an atypical antipsychotic and inverse agonist and antagonist of the serotonin receptors. It is primarily used in the treatment of psychosis in patients with Parkinson’s disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vilazodone is a novel antidepressant with a dual mechanism of action, functioning as both an SSRI and a 5HT1A receptor partial agonist, making it effective for treating depression with fewer sexual side effects. Other Options listed are atypical antipsychotics and not classified as antidepressants.
