questions.text: Match the following bacteria with the drug of choice used for each? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3

 

  1. Vancomycin is Drug of Choice for Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) – It acts by inhibiting the cell wall synthesis and is a bactericidal drug.
  2. Metronidazole drug of choice against anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides.
  3. Meropenem is used in infections caused by Klebsiella. Klebsiella is known to produce ESBL (Extended Spectrum Beta Lactamases). Carbapenems are not hydrolyzed by ESBL. Therefore, carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, ertapenem are indicated in the treatment of infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria.
  4. Penicillin like amoxicillin, ampicillin can be used in H. influenzae infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Metronidazole is the drug of choice for anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides.
  • Vancomycin is the drug of choice for infections caused by MRSA.
  • Penicillins like amoxicillin and ampicillin are used for Haemophilus influenzae infections.
  • Meropenem is used for infections caused by Klebsiella, particularly ESBL-producing strains.

questions.text: A patient who was receiving warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation was prescribed a cephalosporin antibiotic to treat a lower respiratory tract infection. He returned to the hospital after developing hemarthrosis. Which of the following cephalosporins is most likely to have caused this? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cefoperazone

 

  • The development of hemarthrosis (bleeding into a joint) in a patient on warfarin therapy, after starting a cephalosporin antibiotic, raises concerns about drug interactions that can potentiate the anticoagulant effect of warfarin.
  • Warfarin inhibits the enzyme Vitamin K Epoxide Reductase (VKOR) which in turn inhibits the gamma carboxylation of Glutamic acid residues of factors II, VII , IX and X.
  • Cefoperazone is a 3rd generation cephalosporin that contains methylthiotetrazole (MTT) group. This also inhibits the VKOR enzyme, just like warfarin. Therefore, in a patient who is already on warfarin therapy, this can lead to bleeding manifestations.
  • Cefotetan, Cefamandole are other cephalosporins that contain the MTT group.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cefixime: This is a third-generation cephalosporin and is not known to have a significant interaction with warfarin that would increase the risk of bleeding.

 

Option C. Ceftobiprole: As a newer cephalosporin, ceftobiprole is not commonly associated with significant interactions with warfarin that would lead to increased bleeding risk.

 

Option D. Ceftazidime: This is another third-generation cephalosporin, and like cefixime, it is not commonly associated with interactions that significantly enhance the anticoagulant effect of warfarin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cefoperazone is the cephalosporin most likely to cause hemarthrosis in a patient on warfarin therapy due to its MTT group, which can inhibit the VKOR enzyme and potentiate the anticoagulant effects of warfarin. Other cephalosporins like cefixime, ceftobiprole, and ceftazidime do not have this interaction and are less likely to cause such bleeding complications.

questions.text: Identify the histological structure indicated by the arrows in the given lung tissue section. (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory bronchus

 

 

 

The image shows a histological section of the lung with an arrow indicating a structure involved in gas exchange. The key features to identify include the presence of air spaces and the type of epithelium lining these spaces.

 

  • Respiratory Bronchus: This structure is part of the respiratory zone of the lung, where gas exchange occurs. It is lined by simple cuboidal epithelium transitioning to simple squamous epithelium as it progresses into the alveolar ducts and sacs. The respiratory bronchus is characterized by the presence of alveoli arising from its walls, indicating the start of the gas exchange process.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alveolar sac: Alveolar sacs are the terminal ends of the respiratory tree where clusters of alveoli are found. They are not the initial structures for gas exchange but are rather the sites where the alveoli are grouped.

 

Option C. Terminal bronchiole: Terminal bronchioles are the last part of the conducting zone and do not participate in gas exchange. They are lined with simple cuboidal epithelium without the presence of alveoli in their walls.

 

Option D. Intrapulmonary bronchiole: Intrapulmonary bronchioles refer to the bronchioles within the lung tissue that are part of the conducting zone and do not participate directly in gas exchange.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The respiratory bronchus is the structure where gas exchange begins in the lung, identified by its simple cuboidal epithelium and the presence of alveoli arising from its walls.

questions.text: Capgras syndrome is commonly seen in which type of dementia? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dementia with lewy body

 

Capgras syndrome is a type of delusion of misidentification where the patient believes that a familiar person has been replaced by a similar-looking stranger.

 

While Capgras syndrome is usually seen in Schizophrenia, it can also occur in patients with dementia. Among the various types of dementia, Capgras syndrome is most commonly associated with Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), followed by Alzheimer's disease. In a patient with Capgras syndrome and dementia, the patient may believe that their spouse or a family member has been replaced by an identical impostor, leading to conflicts and distress.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alzheimer's disease is the second most common type of dementia associated with Capgras syndrome, after dementia with Lewy bodies.

 

Option C. Vascular dementia is not typically associated with Capgras syndrome.

 

Option D. Frontotemporal dementia is not commonly associated with Capgras syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Capgras syndrome, a delusion of misidentification where a patient believes a familiar person has been replaced by an identical impostor, is most commonly seen in dementia with Lewy bodies, followed by Alzheimer's disease.

questions.text: In the given transverse section of the cerebellum, the red-highlighted region derives its blood supply from a branch of which of the following arteries? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Vertebral artery

 

 

 

The red shaded area in the given image indicates a portion of the lateral medulla. The blood supply to this area is provided by the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery. This area is typically involved in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

 

  • Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA): This artery is a branch of the vertebral artery and supplies the lateral part of the medulla and the inferior part of the cerebellum. Damage to this artery can lead to lateral medullary syndrome, characterized by various neurological deficits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior cerebellar artery: This artery supplies the superior part of the cerebellum and does not supply the lateral medulla.

 

Option B. Posterior cerebral artery: This artery primarily supplies the occipital lobe and parts of the temporal lobe, not the lateral medulla.

 

Option D. Basilar artery: While the basilar artery gives rise to the superior cerebellar artery and the anterior inferior cerebellar artery, it does not directly supply the lateral medulla. The vertebral arteries, which form the basilar artery, give rise to PICA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA), which is a branch of the vertebral artery, supplies the lateral medulla. Damage to this artery can result in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

questions.text:
Arrange the following steps of ventricular action potential in the correct order: (INICET Nov 2022)

 

  1. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels
  2. Repolarizing K+ currents
  3. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels
  4. Transient outward flow of potassium
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C, D, A, B

 

The ventricular action potential is characterized by a sequence of changes in membrane potential and ionic currents. The correct sequence is as follows:

 

  1. C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels: This is the initial depolarization phase (Phase 0). When the membrane potential reaches the threshold, voltage-gated sodium channels open, leading to a rapid influx of Na+ ions and a sharp rise in membrane potential.
  2. D. Transient outward flow of potassium: This corresponds to Phase 1. Shortly after the peak of the action potential, transient outward K+ channels open, causing a brief efflux of K+ ions which results in a slight repolarization.
  3. A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels: This is Phase 2, the plateau phase. Voltage-gated L-type calcium channels open, allowing Ca2+ to enter the cell. The influx of Ca2+ is balanced by the efflux of K+ through delayed rectifier K+ channels, maintaining a plateau in the membrane potential.
  4. B. Repolarizing K+ currents: This is Phase 3. The Ca2+ channels close, but the delayed rectifier K+ channels remain open, leading to a net efflux of K+ and returning the membrane potential to its resting value.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence for ventricular action potential is as follows:

 

C. Opening of voltage-gated sodium channels

D. Transient outward flow of potassium

A. Opening of voltage-gated calcium channels

B. Repolarizing K+ currents
